awd_titl_txt: PEPIG: Empowering Academic Partnership with Federal Safety and Security Priorities
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing shortage of people with data science expertise working in federal agencies.  This project will help overcome this problem, by providing fellowship opportunities to faculty, postdocs, research scientist, graduate student, and senior undergraduates to carry out research in data science priority areas within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).  Participant will be co-located with DHS mentors and staff. The program broadly benefits the data ecosystem by serving as a backbone for research collaboration on pressing United states safety and security concerns.

The goals of this program are to support academics in developing industry and government relationships for research collaboration and career success; prepare students for the workforce landscape in data science, computing, and Big Data research; and create a diverse Big Data pipeline from university research through to real-world impact in government service.  The proposed program is modeled after the innovative and successful Big Data Regional Innovation South Hub's Program to Empower Partnerships with Industry and Government (PEPI-G) program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Program to Empower Partnership with Industry and Government (PEPI-G)  funded 3 to 12-month fellowship experiences for researchers including faculty, postdocs, research scientists, graduate students, and senior undergraduates.  Fellows engaged with government and industry partners to launch new collaborations and engage in research projects.  Fellows were selected annually from a competitive regional and national applicant pool, based on their merit, and individual goal alignment with each of the program partners.  Each fellow received a monthly stipend and travel support for their contributions to the program and their extensive professional development.  During the program, twelve fellows contributed to the development of the strategic plans for integrating AI/ML into organizational partner divisions within our government and industry partner network. Fellows also worked on relevant research projects in model explainability, adversarial patches, quantum technologies, cyber threat hunting, chemistry prediction, cybercrime, anomaly detection in large graphs, statistics, Big Data computing,  visual analytics, parallel processing, and Internet-of-things (IoT).  Numerous participants were asked to return for future fellowship cycles or extended by the program partner to continue their experiences. A testament to the impact and success of the PEPI-G program is that 100% of faculty fellows established research relationships with industry or government partners that extended beyond the program duration. 


Last Modified: 12/05/2022
Modified by: Renata Rawlings-Goss
